newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan third-quarter GDP up 5.61 percent - official.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan third-quarter GDP up 5.61 percent - official.

text.p: Taiwan's gross domestic product grew a year-on-year 5.61 percent in the third quarter, an official of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said on Friday.

The directorate forecast full-year 1996 GDP growth would reach only 5.7 percent, a significant downward revision from its most recent forecast of 5.89 percent and below the 1995 full-year growth rate of 6.0 percent.

The directorate, in a quarterly statement, gave no reason for the downward revision of the 1996 growth forecast, an apparent reflection of the economy's failure to reach its third-quarter target of 6.09 percent.
The third-quarter GDP showing was a slight improvement over the 5.42 percent registered in the second quarter, showing that a recovery is under way -- albeit more slowly than hoped.

The agency forecast fourth-quarter growth of 6.6 percent, a relatively ambitious target that it justified on the basis of an expected big increase in imports and likely gradual increases in domestic investment and consumption.

The directorate said attributed the lacklustre third-quarter performance to lower-than-expected growth in the financial and construction industries and domestic investment that was also below expectations.
Third-quarter GDP performance was well below expectations of local economists, who as recently as Monday had forecast that growth would come in at a modest 5.9-6.0 percent.
Economists have attributed the frustrating sluggishness of Taiwan's recovery to a crackdown on gang-linked business as well as a slower-than-expected rebound in exports.
